steps.text: In the previous tutorial, you witnessed how hosts evolved to send packets to other hosts. This evolution in communication has undoubtedly propelled advancements in computing significantly forward.

Imagine attempting to communicate with your friends without the means to propagate information. If you needed to speak with someone who had just left for another state, your only option would be to physically chase after them and deliver the message in person.
Storing all possible communication routes would impose a significant burden on a computer's memory. In such cases, utilizing a "Switch" becomes a more efficient solution.
That may have been overwhelming with information. The key takeaway is that switches enable communication to occur without the need to go directly to the destination.

In the scenario mentioned earlier, if you can't directly communicate with the person you need to reach, you might convey your message to someone who will eventually meet them in person and pass along the information on your behalf.
Once again, you're going to simulate a ping to establish connectivity from the source host to the destination host.
This time, you're going to route your packet through a switch to ensure that the information reaches its destination.
